string-array.name: strings_learn_getting_started_toptext
string-array.item: Pinyin sounds are composed of an \"initial\" and a \"final.\" Most finals are full pinyin sounds in themselves such as the most basic final, \"a.\" The \"a\" final is pronounced like the \"a\" in the English word \"father.\"
The \"b,\" \"p,\" \"m,\" and \"f\" initials are pronounced like their English counterparts.

string-array.name: strings_learn_getting_started_bottomtext
string-array.item: Tap the pinyin to hear how it is pronounced.
Note that some initial-final combinations do not exist in Mandarin.

string-array.name: learn_more_simple_sounds_toptext
string-array.item: The \"d\", \"t\", \"n\" and \"l\" initials are pronounced as they would be in English.

string-array.name: learn_adding_o_finals_toptext
string-array.item: The Mandarin \"o\" final by itself only combines with the \"b\", \"p\", \"m\" and \"f\" initials.
The \"o\" in the \"ong\" final is very similar to the English \"oh\" sound. That is, \"long\" is pronounced \"l-oh-ng\", not \"l-ah-ng\".
The \"ou\" final is very similar to the English \"oh\" sound, except one\'s lips start to round towards the end. This creates a slightly more exaggerated \"oo\" sound at the end.

string-array.name: learn_adding_o_finals_bottomtext
string-array.item: While not completely foreign, this sound is very different from any sound in English.
The \"ong\" final is not a valid pinyin sound unless combined with an initial. It also does not combine with the \"b\", \"p\", \"m\" and \"f\" initials.
This final combines with all of the initials we\'ve covered so far except for the \"o\" final.

string-array.name: learn_challenging_initials_i_toptext
string-array.item: The \"s\" initial is pronounced just like the English \"s\" with the tip of the tongue placed against the back of the bottom front teeth.
The \"c\" initial is pronounced like \"ts\".
At first, the \"z\" initial might sound similar to the \"c\", but they are actually quite different. While the \"c\" can be thought of as a \"ts\" sound, the \"z\" is more like a \"dz\" sound.
Before jumping in and practicing each sound, take a moment to contrast some of the initials side-by-side, expecially the \"z\" and \"c\" initials.

string-array.name: learn_challenging_initials_i_bottomtext
string-array.item: While no words in English start with this sound, several words do end with this sound. For example, \"hits\", \"fits\" and \"bits\" all end with the Mandarin \"c\" sound.
This sound also does not occur at the beginning of any English sounds, but it does occur at the end of words like \"bids\", \"kids\" and \"lids\".

string-array.name: learn_challenging_initials_ii_toptext
string-array.item: The Mandarin \"sh\" and English \"sh\" sounds are very similar, except the tongue should be slightly curled upward against the top plate of the mouth when speaking the Mandarin \"sh\" initial.
By beginning with the same tongue placement as the \"sh\" initial but instead speaking a \"ch\" sound, you will produce the Mandarin \"ch\" initial
Another initial that starts with the same tongue position is the \"zh\" initial. Simply curl the tongue up just behind the top teeth and speak an English \"j\" sound to reproduce the Mandarin \"zh\".

At first, the Mandarin \"r\" can seem quite foreign, but it does exist in some English words. First, say the English word \"leisure\" a few times. Notice that right in the middle of the word the tongue is curled up like the \"sh\", \"ch\" and \"zh\" sounds. This buzzing-like sound in the middle of \"leisure\" is like the \"r\" initial.
Getting proficient with these initials will make you sound like a pro, so take a minute to review some of them.

string-array.name: learn_wrapping_up_a_and_o_toptext
string-array.item: The Mandarin \"g\", \"k\" and \"h\" initials are not foreign to English speakers; however, because Mandarin speakers generally put less emphasis on initials, it can be easy to confuse the \"g\" and \"k\" sounds.
These initials combine with all of the \"a\" finals as well as with the \"ong\" and \"ou\" finals.

string-array.name: learn_adding_e_to_the_mix_toptext
string-array.item: It sounds funny, but the \"e\" final sounds something like the noise someone might make when seeing something they really don\'t like. Or perhaps closer to the sound a person might make when getting hit in the stomach. The pronunciation is similar in the \"en\" and \"eng\" finals as well. However, the \"er\" final is more similar to the English word \"are\".
While not a sound itself, the \"ei\" final combines with many initials to form pinyin sounds. It is pronounced similar to the English word \"a\".

string-array.name: learn_adding_e_to_the_mix_bottomtext
string-array.item: As you may have noticed, the \"er\" final does not combine with any initials.

string-array.name: learn_effort_with_e_toptext
string-array.item: Most of the \"e\" finals also combine with the more challenging initials that we covered earlier.

string-array.name: learn_effort_with_e_bottomtext
string-array.item: Note again that the \"er\" final does not combine with any initials.

string-array.name: learn_introducing_i_toptext
string-array.item: In general, the Mandarin \"i\" is pronounced like \"ee\", much like the \"i\" in the English word \"ski\". When written by itself, it is written as a \"y\".
The \"iu\" final is actually an abbreviation for \"iou\", so it is pronounced as \"ee-oh\".
Here are the rest of the initial combinations with these \"i\" finals.

string-array.name: learn_expanding_i_toptext
string-array.item: Most of the new \"i\" finals in this section are pronounced as expected. The exception is \"ian\", which is generally pronounced like \"ee-en\".
Note again that \"bian\", \"pian\" and \"main\" are pronounced as \"bee-en\", \"pee-en\" and \"mee-en\" and NOT as \"bee-an\", \"pee-an\" and \"mee-an\".
Here are the remaining \"i\" final combinations.

string-array.name: learn_exceptions_with_i_toptext
string-array.item: When combining wiht the \"s\", \"c\" and \"z\" initials, the \"i\" final is no longer pronounced as an \"ee\" sound.
Combining \"sh\", \"ch\", \"zh\" or \"r\" initials with the \"i\" final also results with a unique sound.

string-array.name: learn_exceptions_with_i_bottomtext
string-array.item: Try saying the (American) English word \"shirt\" a few times, but stop before the \"r\" sound gets too string. This is a reasonable starting point for pronouncing \"shi\".

string-array.name: learn_challenging_initials_iii_toptext
string-array.item: The \"x\", \"q\" and \"j\" initials are very similar to the English \"sh\", \"ch\", and \"j\" sounds, except the tongue is placed just below the bottom front teeth when pronouncing these sounds.

string-array.name: learn_challenging_initials_iii_bottomtext
string-array.item: Note that the tongue being at the bottom of the mouth rather than at the top of the mouth is what distinguishes these sounds from the \"sh\", \"ch\" and \"zh\" initials.

string-array.name: learn_the_u_final_toptext
string-array.item: The Mandarin \"u\" final is always pronounced by rounding the lips and making an \"oo\" sound. When it occurs at the beginning of a sound, it is written as a \"w\".
These finals are pronounced as one might expect. Start wiht a \"u\" sound then pronounce the remaining final.

string-array.name: learn_the_u_final_bottomtext
string-array.item: Notice that \"uei\" is abbreviated as \"ui\" when combined with an initial. Also, \"uen\" is abbreviated as \"un\".

string-array.name: learn_a_big_step_with_u_toptext
string-array.item: There are no new initials or finals in this section, but some of these combinations will take some practice for most English speakers.
As you can see, the \"challenging initials\" combine with almost all of the \"u\" finals.
Here is the last set of pinyin sounds for this section.

string-array.name: learn_concluding_u_toptext
string-array.item: Again, there are no new initials or finals in this section.

string-array.name: learn_concluding_u_bottomtext
string-array.item: As you may have noticed, the \"ueng\" final does not combine with any initials and exists only as \"weng\"

string-array.name: learn_last_but_not_least_toptext
string-array.item: The ü sound can be a bit daunting and will probably require some practice. To pronounce this sound, round your lips as if you\'re about to say \"oo\", but say \"ee\" instead.
It might feel a bit like patting your head and rubbing your stomach at the same time, but with some practice this sound will become quite natural.

When combined with the \"x\", \"q\" and \"j\" initials, the \"ü\" is usually written as a \"u\". Don\'t let this confuse you! Regardless of how the sounds are written, these initials combine with the ü sounds.

string-array.name: learn_last_but_not_least_bottomtext
string-array.item: Keep your lips rounded the whole time!
Also, keep in mind that \"nü\" and \"lü\" are distinct from \"nu\" and \"lu\".
